docs.title: Interactive Course Portal
docs.text: Welcome to your complete physics learning environment. Explore modules, practice problems, simulations, and reviews — all in one place.

docs.title: 🚀 Start Here
docs.text: - :rocket: **Begin Learning**    ---   Start with the fundamentals of 1D and 2D motion using calculus.    [Start Week 1 →](week1/index.md)  - :book: **View Syllabus**    ---   Course structure, grading, expectations, and weekly schedule.    [Open Syllabus →](syllabus.md)  - :mag: **Search the Course**    ---   Instantly find any formula, example, or topic using the search bar.    Use the 🔍 icon in the top-right.

docs.title: 📘 Course Modules
docs.text: - :one: **Week 1 — Kinematics**    ---   Motion in 1D, derivatives, integrals, free fall, displacement, velocity, acceleration.    [Go to Week 1 →](week1/index.md)  - :two: **Week 2 — Vectors & 2D Motion**    ---   Components, unit vectors, dot product, projectile motion, circular motion.    [Go to Week 2 →](week2/index.md)  - :three: **Week 3 — Forces & Newton’s Laws**    ---   Dynamics, free-body diagrams, friction, tension, Newton’s laws, applications.    [Go to Week 3 →](week3/index.md)  - :four: **Week 4 — Work & Energy**    ---   Work-energy theorem, kinetic & potential energy, conservative vs. non-conservative forces.    [Go to Week 4 →](week4/index.md)  - :five: **Week 5 — Momentum & Collisions**    ---   Impulse-momentum theorem, elastic/inelastic collisions, center of mass.    [Go to Week 5 →](week5/index.md)  - :six: **Week 6 — Rotational Motion**    ---   Rotational kinematics & dynamics, torque, moment of inertia.    [Go to Week 6 →](week6/index.md)  - :seven: **Week 7 — SHM & Gravitation**    ---   Springs, pendulums, oscillations, universal gravitation, orbital motion.    [Go to Week 7 →](week7/index.md)  - :eight: **Week 8 — Thermodynamics**    ---   Temperature, heat transfer, ideal gases, first law of thermodynamics.    [Go to Week 8 →](week8/index.md)

docs.title: 🧪 Interactive Tools
docs.text: - :chart_with_upwards_trend: **Simulations**    ---   Test motion graphs, forces, energy, and waves with interactive demos.    *Coming soon.*  - :pencil2: **Practice Problems**    ---   Challenge problems with instant solutions to test your understanding.    *Coming soon.*  - :zap: **Exam Reviews**    ---   Guided review modules for each exam with summaries & practice quizzes.    *Coming soon.*

docs.title: 🧩 About the Course
docs.text:
This course combines physics + calculus to help you master:

  • motion in 1D & 2D
  • forces & Newton’s laws
  • rotational dynamics
  • energy & momentum
  • oscillations & waves
  • thermodynamics

You will learn to: - model physical systems - solve problems using derivatives & integrals - build intuition with diagrams & graphs - analyze real-world phenomena

# 🎉 Ready to Begin? [Start Week 1 →](week1/index.md){ .md-button .md-button--primary .md-button--large }

docs.title: 🧭 Week 1 — Units, Dimensions & 1D Motion (Illustrated, Tiered Mastery)
docs.text:
Welcome to Week 1 of College Physics 201.

This module is designed so that a motivated student can teach themselves the Week 1 material using:

  • Illustrated explanations
  • Tiered mastery (core → deeper → advanced)
  • Examples and practice with hidden solutions
  • Graphs and diagrams from your lecture slides (Ch. 1 & Ch. 3)
0. How to Use This Page Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application
  • Each section is collapsible — click the bar to expand it.
  • Inside most sections you’ll see tabs:
  • Core Idea — what you must know
  • Deeper Reasoning — why it works and how to think about it

  • Advanced Application — calculus, graphs, and more challenging thinking

  • Many problems have hidden solutions. Try them before opening the answer.

Learning physics is like building a mental model of how the universe behaves. This page is structured so you can: - get the big picture first - then drill into detail only when you’re ready - then test yourself

As you go through, ask yourself: - “Where would this show up in real life?” - “Could I explain this to someone else?” - “What equation or graph represents this situation?”

1. Physical Quantities, Units, and Measurement Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Physics describes the world using measurable quantities: - length, time, mass, temperature, etc. - each must have a unit (meters, seconds, kilograms, kelvins…)

We use the SI (International System of Units) as a common language.

Quantity Unit Symbol Length meter m Mass kilogram kg Time second s Temperature kelvin K Electric current ampere A

Visual from your slides:

A “number” without a unit is meaningless in physics.

Compare: - “The car went 30” → 30 what? - “The car went 30 m” vs “30 mi” vs “30 km” → very different physical situations.

Units also hide physical scales: - meters vs nanometers vs light-years - seconds vs microseconds vs years

Your slide likely showing different scales:

This helps students see that the same laws apply from atoms to galaxies.

When you later do more advanced physics (EM, quantum, thermo), being sloppy with units leads to: - wrong answers - confusion about what an equation actually means - difficulty catching mistakes

Habit to build now: - Always write the unit next to your answer. - Always check if unit types “match” on both sides of equations.

2. SI Prefixes and Unit Conversions (Factor–Label Method) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

We use prefixes to handle very large or small numbers:

Prefix Symbol Factor kilo k \(10^3\) mega M \(10^6\) giga G \(10^9\) milli m \(10^{-3}\) micro μ \(10^{-6}\) nano n \(10^{-9}\)

From your slides:

We do conversions using the factor–label method (multiplying by 1 cleverly).

Example: Convert 60 mph to m/s

\[ 60\ \frac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}} \cdot \frac{1609\ \text{m}}{1\ \text{mi}} \cdot \frac{1\ \text{hr}}{3600\ \text{s}} = 26.8\ \text{m/s} \]

Each “conversion factor” is just a fancy version of:

\[ \frac{\text{same quantity in different units}}{\text{same quantity in original units}} = 1 \]

So we are multiplying by 1, but in a way that changes units.

In more advanced problems, you might convert: - km/h to m/s - g/cm\(^3\) to kg/m\(^3\) - J to eV (electron-volts)

Practice problem:

Convert \( 3.5\ \text{g/cm}^3 \) into kg/m\(^3\).

Show Solution \[ 3.5\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^3} \cdot \frac{1\ \text{kg}}{1000\ \text{g}} \cdot \left(\frac{100\ \text{cm}}{1\ \text{m}}\right)^3 = 3.5 \cdot \frac{1}{1000} \cdot (10^6) = 3500\ \frac{\text{kg}}{\text{m}^3} \] 3. Dimensions and Dimensional Analysis Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Dimensions represent the type of quantity, not the unit.

  • Length: \([L]\)
  • Time: \([T]\)
  • Mass: \([M]\)

Examples: [ \text{Velocity} : [L][T^{-1}] ] [ \text{Acceleration} : [L][T^{-2}] ] [ \text{Force} : [M][L][T^{-2}] ]

You can use dimensions to check if an equation could possibly be correct.

Suppose someone proposes:

\[ v = 3t + 7x \]
  • Left-hand side: \(v \rightarrow [L/T]\)
  • Right-hand side:
  • \(3t \rightarrow [T]\)
  • \(7x \rightarrow [L]\)

You cannot add \([T]\) and \([L]\). Therefore, the equation is nonsense physically.

Dimensional analysis doesn’t prove an equation is right, but it can tell you if it’s definitely wrong.

Often, we know: - the relevant quantities (e.g., \(g\), \(h\), \(v_0\)), and - the dimension we want (e.g., time [T])

Dimensional analysis can guide us to plausible forms of relationships.

It’s also very helpful in checking your work in exams.

Visual from your slides:

4. Position and Displacement Along a Line Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Position \(x(t)\) tells you where an object is along a 1D axis. Displacement is the change in position:

\[ \Delta x = x_f - x_i \]

It can be positive (forward), negative (backwards) or zero.

From your Ch. 3 slides:

Position depends on your choice of origin. If you choose \(x=0\) at one place vs another, the numeric values change, but physics does not.

Displacement cares only about start and end, not the path taken.

If \(x(t)\) is given as a function (e.g., a polynomial), we can: - compute displacement over a time interval: \(x(t_2)-x(t_1)\) - compute average velocity: \(\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\)

Example:

[ x(t) = 2t^2 - 4t + 1 ] From \(t=1\) to \(t=3\):

\[ \Delta x = x(3)-x(1) \] Show Solution

[ x(3)=2(9)-4(3)+1=18-12+1=7 ] [ x(1)=2(1)-4(1)+1=2-4+1=-1 ] [ \Delta x = 7 - (-1) = 8\ \text{m} ]

5. Average vs Instantaneous Velocity Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Average velocity over a time interval:

\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \]

Instantaneous velocity is the velocity at one instant:

\[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} \]

On a position–time graph: - average velocity ↔ slope of a secant line - instantaneous velocity ↔ slope of the tangent line

From your slides:

Average velocity is like “overall change”: “From 1:00 to 1:05, my position changed by 500 m, so on average I moved 100 m/min.”

Instantaneous velocity zooms in on one time: “Exactly at 1:02:30, what was my speed and direction?”

Conceptual graph from your slides:

Given: [ x(t) = t^3 - 4t + 2 ]

  • Average velocity from \(t=1\) to \(t=2\)
  • Instantaneous velocity at \(t=1\)
Show Solution \[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 3t^2 - 4 \]

Average from 1 to 2:

[ x(2) = 8 - 8 + 2 = 2 ] [ x(1) = 1 - 4 + 2 = -1 ] [ \bar{v} = \frac{2 - (-1)}{2-1} = 3\ \text{m/s} ]

Instantaneous at \(t=1\):

\[ v(1) = 3(1)^2-4 = -1\ \text{m/s} \]

Negative means motion is in the negative direction at that instant.

6. Acceleration: Changing Velocity Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity:

\[ a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} \]

On a velocity–time graph: - the slope is the acceleration

Slide illustration:

There are several ways velocity can change: - speed increases - speed decreases - direction reverses

All of these involve acceleration, even if the speed is momentarily zero.

For constant acceleration: [ a = \text{constant} \Rightarrow v(t) = v_0 + at,\quad x(t) = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 ]

Suppose: [ a(t) = 6t,\quad v(0) = 3,\quad x(0)=0 ]

Then: [ v(t) = \int 6t\,dt = 3t^2 + C ]

Using \(v(0)=3\): [ 3(0)^2 + C = 3 \Rightarrow C = 3 ]

\[ v(t) = 3t^2+3 \]

Then: [ x(t) = \int (3t^2+3)\,dt = t^3 + 3t + C_2 ]

Using \(x(0)=0\) gives \(C_2=0\).

\[ x(t) = t^3 + 3t \] 7. Free Fall & Constant Acceleration (1D Kinematics) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Near Earth’s surface, ignoring air resistance:

\[ a = g \approx 9.8\ \text{m/s}^2 \quad (\text{downward}) \]

If we take upward as positive, then:

\[ a = -g \]

Kinematic equations (constant acceleration):

[ v = v_0 + at ] [ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 ] [ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0) ]

Your slide visual:

Free fall includes: - dropping an object (\(v_0 = 0\)) - throwing an object upward - throwing an object downward

All share: - same acceleration magnitude (if air resistance is negligible) - parabolic position–time graphs - linear velocity–time graphs

Example — Dropped from 20 m

\[ x_0 = 20\ \text{m},\quad v_0 = 0,\quad a=-9.8\ \text{m/s}^2 \]

Position:

\[ x(t) = 20 + 0\cdot t + \frac{1}{2}(-9.8)t^2 = 20 - 4.9 t^2 \]

Time to hit the ground: set \(x(t)=0\):

\[ 20 - 4.9t^2 = 0 \Rightarrow t^2=\frac{20}{4.9} \Rightarrow t \approx 2.02\ \text{s} \]

Velocity on impact:

\[ v = v_0 + at = -9.8(2.02) \approx -19.8\ \text{m/s} \]

Negative indicates downward direction.

8. Worked Examples (Tiered) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Example 1 — From Position to Velocity and Acceleration

\[ x(t) = 4t^3 - 2t \] \[ v(t) = 12t^2 - 2 \] \[ a(t) = 24t \]

Graph-style slide:

  • Position is cubic → velocity quadratic → acceleration linear.
  • As time increases:
  • velocity grows faster
  • acceleration keeps changing (not constant)

Example 2 — Car Accelerating from Rest

A car starts from rest and accelerates at \(4\ \text{m/s}^2\) for 5 s.

\[ v = v_0 + at = 0 + 4(5) = 20\ \text{m/s} \] \[ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 = 0 + 0 + \frac{1}{2}(4)(25) = 50\ \text{m} \]

Example 3 — Free-Fall Upward Throw

A ball is thrown upward at \(12\ \text{m/s}\). Maximum height (using \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a\Delta x\) with final \(v=0\)):

\[ 0 = (12)^2 + 2(-9.8)\Delta x \Rightarrow \Delta x = \frac{144}{19.6} \approx 7.35\ \text{m} \] 9. Practice Problems (Try First, Then Expand) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application & Solutions
  1. Given \(x(t)=2t^3 - 5t^2 + 7\), find \(v(t)\) and \(a(t)\).
  2. A car accelerates from rest at \(4\ \text{m/s}^2\) for 5 s. Find distance traveled.
  3. A ball is thrown upward at \(12\ \text{m/s}\). Find max height.
  4. Convert 45 mph to m/s.
  5. If \(v(t)=6t\) and \(x(0)=0\), find \(x(t)\).

Think for each: - What is given? (position? velocity? acceleration?) - Do I need a derivative or integral? - Is this constant acceleration?

Problem 1 Solution

[ x(t)=2t^3 - 5t^2 + 7 ] [ v(t)=\frac{dx}{dt}=6t^2 - 10t ] [ a(t)=\frac{dv}{dt}=12t - 10 ]

Problem 2 Solution \[ x = \frac{1}{2}at^2 = \frac{1}{2}(4)(25)=50\ \text{m} \] Problem 3 Solution \[ h = \frac{v_0^2}{2g} = \frac{144}{19.6} \approx 7.35\ \text{m} \] Problem 4 Solution \[ 45\ \text{mph} \approx 20.1\ \text{m/s} \] Problem 5 Solution

[ v(t)=6t \Rightarrow x(t)=\int 6t\,dt = 3t^2 + C ] Using \(x(0)=0\) gives \(C=0\). Thus: [ x(t)=3t^2 ]

10. Summary Sheet (Exam-Focused) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Definitions

\[ v(t)=\frac{dx}{dt} \qquad a(t)=\frac{dv}{dt} \]

Constant-Acceleration Equations

[ v = v_0 + at ] [ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 ] [ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x-x_0) ]

Key Ideas

  • Units & dimensions must be consistent.
  • Derivative ↔ slope of graph.
  • Integral ↔ area under graph.
  • Free fall ≈ constant acceleration due to gravity.

Ask yourself if you can: - explain what each symbol means physically - sketch a rough graph for each motion situation - decide which equation to use based on what’s known

On a test, the hardest problems often combine: - reading a graph - interpreting a word problem - choosing a kinematic equation - performing a unit conversion - checking units/dimensions at the end

Practice spotting all of these elements in a single problem.

docs.title: 🧭 Week 2 — Vectors, Components, and 2D Motion
docs.text:
Welcome to Week 2! This module teaches how to represent quantities in two dimensions — a critical step for real physics.

You’ll learn vectors, components, projectiles, and how calculus applies in 2D motion.

Click on sections to expand and learn at your own pace.

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of Week 2, you will be able to:

  • Represent physical quantities as vectors
  • Break vectors into x and y components
  • Use unit vectors
  • Add, subtract, and scale vectors
  • Compute dot products
  • Analyze 2D motion using components
  • Solve projectile motion problems
  • Use reasoning + calculus to understand curved motion

docs.title: 📘 1. Introduction to Vectors
docs.text:
1.1 What is a Vector?

A vector has both:

  • magnitude (how much)
  • direction (which way)

Examples: - velocity - acceleration - displacement - force

Scalar ≠ vector - a scalar has magnitude only - example: mass, temperature, energy

1.2 Vector Notation

Common notations:

\[ \vec{A},\quad \mathbf{A},\quad \langle A_x, A_y \rangle \]

Components: [ \vec{A} = \langle A_x,\ A_y \rangle ]

Magnitude: [ |\vec{A}| = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2} ]

Unit vector form: [ \vec{A} = A_x \hat{i} + A_y \hat{j} ]

Deep Explanation — Why Physics Uses Components

Real-world motion rarely happens in a straight line.

By breaking motion into: [ x\text{-direction} \quad \text{and} \quad y\text{-direction} ] we can:

  • treat each dimension independently
  • solve harder problems using simple 1D equations
  • combine them at the end to get full motion

Example: Projectile motion has: - horizontal motion with constant velocity - vertical motion with constant acceleration

Components allow us to separate these behaviors cleanly.

docs.title: 📘 2. Vector Components
docs.text:
ConceptExampleTry It

Any vector can be broken into x and y components:

\[ A_x = A\cos\theta,\qquad A_y = A\sin\theta \]

This allows you to treat motion separately in each direction.

A 10 m vector at 30° above horizontal:

[ A_x = 10\cos 30^\circ = 8.66 ] [ A_y = 10\sin 30^\circ = 5 ]

A 12 m vector at 60°:

Show Solution

[ A_x = 12\cos 60^\circ = 6 ] [ A_y = 12\sin 60^\circ = 10.39 ]

docs.title: 📘 3. Vector Addition & Subtraction
docs.text:
Click to expand

For vectors: [ \vec{A} = \langle A_x, A_y \rangle,\quad \vec{B} = \langle B_x, B_y \rangle ]

Addition: [ \vec{A} + \vec{B} = \langle A_x + B_x,\ A_y + B_y \rangle ]

Subtraction: [ \vec{A} - \vec{B} = \langle A_x - B_x,\ A_y - B_y \rangle ]

Geometric interpretation: - Tip-to-tail method - Parallelogram rule

docs.title: 📘 4. Dot Product (Optional but powerful)
docs.text:
Understanding the Dot Product (Why it matters)

Definition:

\[ \vec{A}\cdot\vec{B} = A_x B_x + A_y B_y \]

Geometric form:

\[ \vec{A}\cdot\vec{B} = |\vec{A}|\,|\vec{B}|\cos\theta \]

Meaning: - Measures how much two vectors “point in the same direction” - Used heavily in energy & work (Week 4) - Helps find angles between vectors

docs.title: 📘 5. 2D Kinematics Overview
docs.text:
Motion in 2 dimensions is broken into two independent motions:

  • Horizontal (x): constant velocity
  • Vertical (y): constant acceleration
\[ x(t)=v_{0x}t, \qquad y(t)=y_0 + v_{0y} t + \frac{1}{2}(-g)t^2 \]

Acceleration only affects the vertical motion.

Deep Explanation — Why x and y Motion Are Independent

Gravity only pulls downward.

That means: - it changes vertical motion - it does NOT affect horizontal motion

This is why a bullet dropped and a bullet fired horizontally hit the ground at the same time.

docs.title: 📘 6. Projectile Motion
docs.text:
ConceptExampleTry It

A projectile has: - horizontal motion with constant velocity [ x(t)=v_{0x} t ] - vertical motion with constant acceleration [ y(t)=y_0 + v_{0y} t - \frac{1}{2}gt^{2} ]

A ball is launched at \(20\ \text{m/s}\) at 40°.

Components: [ v_{0x} = 20\cos 40^\circ = 15.32 ] [ v_{0y} = 20\sin 40^\circ = 12.86 ]

Launch speed \(15\ \text{m/s}\) at 30°.

Show Solution

[ v_{0x} = 15\cos 30^\circ = 12.99 ] [ v_{0y} = 15\sin 30^\circ = 7.5 ]

docs.title: 🎓 7. Worked Examples
docs.text:
Example 1 — Range of a Projectile

A ball is launched at \(25\ \text{m/s}\) at 35° from ground level.

Components: [ v_{0x} = 25\cos 35^\circ = 20.48 ] [ v_{0y} = 25\sin 35^\circ = 14.34 ]

Time of flight: [ t = \frac{2v_{0y}}{g} = 2.93\ \text{s} ]

Range: [ R=v_{0x}t = 59.97\ \text{m} ]

Example 2 — Maximum Height

Using: [ v_y^2 = v_{0y}^2 - 2g(y - y_0) ]

Max height occurs when: [ v_y = 0 ]

Solve: [ h = \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g} ]

Example 3 — Relative Velocity

A boat moves 5 m/s east in a river flowing 3 m/s north.

\[ \vec{v} = \langle 5,\ 3 \rangle \]

Magnitude: [ |\vec{v}| = \sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = 5.83\ \text{m/s} ]

docs.title: 📝 8. Practice Problems
docs.text:
1. A 12 m vector is at 25° above horizontal. Find components. Show Answer

[ A_x = 12\cos 25^\circ = 10.88 ] [ A_y = 12\sin 25^\circ = 5.07 ]

2. A projectile is launched at 18 m/s at 45°.

Find its horizontal and vertical components.

Show Answer

[ v_{0x} = 18\cos 45^\circ = 12.73 ] [ v_{0y} = 18\sin 45^\circ = 12.73 ]

3. Find the range of a projectile launched at 20 m/s at 30°. Show Answer

[ v_{0x}=17.32,\quad v_{0y}=10 ] [ t = \frac{2v_{0y}}{g} = 2.04\ \text{s} ] [ R = v_{0x} t = 35.3\ \text{m} ]

4. A ball is thrown horizontally at 8 m/s from 10 m height. Show Answer

Time to fall: [ t = \sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}} = 1.43\ \text{s} ]

Horizontal distance: [ x = v_x t = 11.4\ \text{m} ]

5. A boat moves 4 m/s east in a 3 m/s north current. Show Answer

[ \vec{v}=\langle 4,\ 3 \rangle ] [ |\vec{v}| = 5\ \text{m/s} ]

docs.title: 🎉 9. Summary Sheet
docs.text: \[ A_x = A\cos\theta,\quad A_y = A\sin\theta \] \[ x(t)=v_{0x}t \] \[ y(t)=y_0 + v_{0y}t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \] \[ |\vec{A}|=\sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2} \]   # 🎓 Week 2 Complete!
